The government in Nepal is battling on two fronts after the massive earthquake there last weekend - the first, to provide food, shelter and medical help to the millions of people affected - the second, to salvage what is left of its cultural treasures.
The government says at least 70 ancient, sacred sites in the Kathmandu Valley alone have been severely damaged or destroyed.
One of the largest of these is a complex of temples sacred to both Hindus and Buddhists that sits high on a mountaintop on the outskirts of the capital.

As it happens, it was also one of the most damaged by the quake.
